conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the sliders and use the conditions given to find the magnitude of the external force F.
Two small sliders A and B are connected by a light rope and placed on an inclined plane with an angle θ = 37°.
A constant horizontal force F is applied to slider B to the right.
Both sliders are just on the verge of not sliding upwards.
The coefficient of kinetic friction between the sliders and the inclined plane is μ = 0.5, and the maximum static friction is equal to the kinetic friction.
It is known that sin 37° = 0.6, and the gravitational acceleration is g.

premise: Gravitational force: mg acting vertically downward.
conclusion: Slider A has a gravitational force mg acting vertically downward.

premise: Normal force: NA perpendicular to the inclined plane.
conclusion: Slider A has a normal force NA perpendicular to the inclined plane.

premise: Frictional force: fA = μNA acting up the incline.
conclusion: Slider A has a frictional force fA = μNA acting up the incline.

premise: Tension in the rope: T acting up the incline.
conclusion: Slider A has a tension T in the rope acting up the incline.

premise: Gravitational force: mg acting vertically downward.
conclusion: Slider B has a gravitational force mg acting vertically downward.

premise: Normal force: NB perpendicular to the inclined plane.
conclusion: Slider B has a normal force NB perpendicular to the inclined plane.

premise: Frictional force: fB = μNB acting down the incline.
conclusion: Slider B has a frictional force fB = μNB acting down the incline.

premise: Tension in the rope: T acting down the incline.
conclusion: Slider B has a tension T in the rope acting down the incline.

premise: External force: F acting horizontally to the right.
conclusion: Slider B has an external force F acting horizontally to the right.

premise: Along the incline: T = mg sin θ + fA
conclusion: For Slider A, the tension T along the incline is T = mg sin θ + fA.

premise: Perpendicular to the incline: NA = mg cos θ
conclusion: For Slider A, the normal force NA perpendicular to the incline is NA = mg cos θ.
